sp.p: The Devil thou art, down with 'em there, a rescue, a rescue.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Am I a Devil again, nay then there's no fence against a flail, I must give way too.

div.stage: Exit Guiacum and Quickwit locks the Door.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, so, if this was not well play'd, I'll n'er Act part again.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Thou art the best of Actors, and shalt be rewarded accordingly, nor shall honest Numps be forgotten neither.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Odswokers, che can make a Vool of vorty such Doctors as this is.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Your Ladyship would make an admirable Actress, faith Madam, to out-wit the Doctor so artificially—'tis a Masterpiece.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, and before the grave Knight and young Fool's face too.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, and but reasonable Madam, what should a Fool do with so fine a Lady.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: O, Sir your Complement some other time, come whilst we have this opportunity let's into my Closet, and consult about the manner of my escape.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Which is contriv'd methodically in that Letter there, by your Lover, who I hope suddenly shall be happy in his reward too.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: If faithful Love, and an obedient Wife can make him happy, he may assure himself of me, I know his Merit, and have a Soul to prize it.

lg.l: Nor shall the wretched Customs of the World,
That change the sweets of Love t' a sordid Bargain,
Ever corrupt my Nature, wealth is a good addition,
And shall be given by me a Slave to vertue,
And wait upon the kind brave Man I love,
Who Weds a Fool, affronts her humane Nature;
Who can be kind to such a Brutal Creature,
'Tis Wit with Love improves the Marriage Charms,
And such a Man is welcome to my Arms.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: VEL now, as you hope to be de Countess, and keep your six Footmen and your Page, dis is all true vat you tell me.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Every syllable in troth Sir, O fye, upon my Integrity I would not tell ye a Lye for the versal World.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Ver good, vel den I will tell you the rest of your fortune, but first fesh me de Almanack, dat I may tell de good day from de bad, dat is material point.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I'll bring it presently—a Countess, why, well fare thy heart old Ienny, six Footmen and a Page, odsme I'm overjoy'd.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: So, I have squeez'd her as dry as a spunge already, the Heiress in this House, that Sir Charles Romance designs for his Son, only feigns her self mad, and Quickwit is by a Trick to get her away for young Frederick, ha, ha, ha, ha, I warrant he thinks himself as secure of her now, as a Cat is of a Mouse that he has between his Paw, ha, ha, ha, alas poor Fool, but if I aim right, he shall find himself damnably mistaken, for what will I do now, but privately go and discover all to Sir Charles, so get my self a swinging Reward, and Quickwit a Plaguy beating, that shall stick by him this Month, ha, ha, ha, 'gad I love such a mischief with all my heart, how it tickles me, I grow even fat at the conceit on't. O here comes my Countess, I must dispatch this old Fool first, and then away—Mum, now for fortune-telling.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Here's an Almanack and 't please ye.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: O let me see, Iune, Iune, Iune, Iuly. Vere be de
Dog-day, dat he de ver good time to make de Intrigue, let me see, you say you ver born in Iuly.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: The fourteenth and shall please ye.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Oh, Ver good, ver good, now shake your left Arm and your right Leg both together, vich we call in Astrology de simple motion.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Is that right, pray Sir.

div.stage: Shakes her Arm and Leg awkardly.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Yes, yes, dat vill do ver well, dat I must needs say is de ver simple motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: But Sir, you tell me nothing all this while, pray Sir, what good fortune shall I have? and particularly, I beseech ye Sir, to give me leave to ask that question, that we Maids most desire to know, which is, when shall I be married, and please ye?

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Cry Hymen vid a sigh, one, two, tre time so, now sit cross-legg'd, and turn de Gnomon of your face, dat is your nose; pulls her Nose to de North East, dat's right, now smile a little, smile foolishly like, right, now let me feel your pulse; aw ver well, I see now you shall have for your Husband de ver Gentleman dat vas to steal away your Lady.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: What Mr. Quickwit, and shall I be no Countess after all this.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Zoon Metresse have de patience and understand your good Fortune, he shall live to be, let me see, Baron of Barn-elms, and if de Planet, dat I see dere say right, he shall be Duke of Twitnam, Mortlack, and Brainford, go, go presently, find him out, and make de Love to him, for I see by my Art, dat dis is de Critical minute, and ver fit for your purpose—go.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Well, I vow Sir, you have ravished me with your Words Dutchess of Twitnam, Mortlack, and Brainford; why, this is prodigious, Lord to see! how preferment will puff up a body, methinks a Countess is too small a title now.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p:
Hark you, one word more, if he refuse you, take two, tre more of your Female Friend vid good Cudgel, and beat him, vor de Star do appoint
dat way to make soft his Heart and Inclination, fear noting, beat him but soundly, and he shall love you for ever after—Adieu. I must get out and laugh somewhere, or I shall burst.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Dutchess of Twitnam, Mortlack, and Brainford,—O Lord, methinks I don't feel the ground I go on! Well, this is a most admirable Person, as I'm a Christian, and of most profound skill, for he told me some marks about me, as right, as if he had been by when I was brought into the World. Well, if Cudgelling my Lover will make me noble, I'll get them that shall lay it on with a good will In troth, for methinks, I long to be call'd your Grace, your Grace. Lord, how it tickles me, pray Heaven my Brain stand firm, for I've heard these new honours are very intoxicating.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: You'll be sure to be ready, Madam, against twelve at Night.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: As punctual as the Minute, get you but the door open that can let us into the Garden, and for the rest let me alone.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: For that, let me alone, and do'e hear, Numps, be sure you take your opportunity to slip out and acquaint Mr. Frederick, that the Coach may be ready at the time, 'dsheart if we should fail in our business to Night, I should be poyson'd before noon to Morrow, with Pills, Powders, and confounded Potions, which I see are preparing for me yonder: for Heavens sake, how came you to 'scape, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Why, my being obstinate at first, has made the Fool take an opinion, that he can cure me with specificks. 'Tis such a positive Coxcomb, that if he once gets a notion into his Head, there's no removing it, tho never so absurd or ridiculous. Come, Numps, come you along with me, you must carry a Letter for me.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: A Letter for ye, ah, would you were to be folded up into a Letter your self, and I were to carry ye to Mr. Frederick, I'd trudge for ye heartily—I would odswokers, there's my word still.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Well, Numps, he shall know the good service you would do him, but for the present let's part, for fear the Doctor should be prying about my Lord de la Fool—your Lordships most humble—ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Oh, my poor Maister, O, O! odswokers the job goes on rarely.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, I think I'm in as pretty a way now to get five hundred pounds, as heart can wish, nothing but the very Devil or my Friend Cunnington can hinder the happy conclusion now, and I think I have been cunning enough to keep it out of his reach, I know the Rogue will envy my good fortune, but that will breed occasion for more mirth hereafter, and when the Guinneas are in my hand once, I shall have the better gust to rally and laugh at him—O Mrs. Marmalet, your humble Servant.

div.stage: Enter Marmalet, who curtsies to him and smiles affectedly.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yours, sweet Mr. Quickwit, or rather, sweet my Lord, I mean not as in the former counterfeit strain, but in very good truth and reality, I give you your title as it is to be.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Say ye so, Mrs. Marmalet, I would I were to give you a new Gown upon that condition.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Ah my Lord, your Grace must give me more than a new Gown before that comes to pass,—yet it shall happen.

sp.speaker: Quick
sp.p: My Grace, what a Plague does she mean, why hark'e, godd mouldy conserve of Quinces, I thought you had been more busie in packing up your Ladies things, than to stand bant'ring here my Grace, what a Devil art thou Mad?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord, I am not Mad my Lord, you should find me perfect in every part, if your Grace would please to try me.

sp.speaker: Quick
sp.p: Zoons my Grace agen.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: In brief, great Duke it is your Love I seek, on which depends your fortune, on which depends, my making or my marring, behold I stand here suing for your liking, a spotless Maid, a Virgin Cabinet, that fifty years has kept its treasure close, from Spiders, Moths, and from all other Vermin, till now kind fate has given a key to you.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Crack'd, downright Craz'd as I live, this comes of living to be an old-Maid.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Ah, dear my Lord, do not deceive your self, I have my senses right and all things else thank Heaven.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why, what a Plague dost Lord me at this rate then? and talk to me of Treasures, and Cabinets, and Spiders, and Moths, and making, and marring; why ye Queen Elizabeth's Old Fardingale, ye dirty wrinkled worm-eaten Ruff without Starch, ye tarnish'd old fashion'd Picture of mad Hecuba in the Hangings, what dost cant of Love to me for?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Does not my Person nor my Merits move ye, know then, the Stars appoint ye honours, if you Marry me, you shall become a Duke.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Become a Dog, Pox on ye for an old Carrion, is this a time for whimsies.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: It is the time my Lord, the only time, I am told by Art, that if we Marry, we shall both be Noble, I do beseech your Grace believe my Tears, there are great Honours budding.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Honours and budding, what a Devil can this plaguy Hag mean by all this?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Good my Lord, Marry me I do beseech your Grace, rolent.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I wont ye old Fool, pox take ye, I wont I tell ye, and get ye gone, and play your Oafs tricks somewhere else, or I'll kick ye. Marry her, I'd assoon Marry a Lancashire Witch, that was sick of the Plague.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: How, nay then since my hard fate, since no fair means will do, the Stars must have their way.

div.stage: Exit, and re enter presently with two other female Servants arm'd with Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: My Grace and my Lordship, and Marry, ha, ha, ha, 'gad I believe the old Sibil has been regaling her self, with a gill or two of Brandy after Dinner, and her frigid veins having gotten a little warmth, provoke her to think of Marriage, Marriage with a Pox to her.

div.stage: He turns his back, and she strikes him over the Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Dear Sir excuse me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Excuse ye, what a Plague's the matter now.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Tis all for your good, indeed my Lord.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Dsheart ye damm'd Iezabel, be quiet you had best.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: 'Tis much against my good nature, but

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: But, what, ye Devil, but what—are ye bewitch'd

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The Stars will have it so.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: —Oons the Stars.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Do but consent to Marry me, and be a Duke.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ye Crackbrain'd Idiot.

sp.speaker: Serv
sp.p: Of—Twitnam.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Very well, Witch.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mortlack.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Fiends and Furies.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: And Brainford upon my Honour, 'tis pity Love puts on so rough a visage, but 'tis the fates decree; and I must,

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Devil brain ye, 'dsdeath, stand off, for if I get into ye, I will so rattle your bones, ye mouldy, mischievous, wither'd, worm-eaten—

div.stage: Enter Fulvia and Numps in hast.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Lost, lost, ruin'd undown, we are all betray'd and discover'd—how now, what's the matter here.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A Sibil, a Succubus. 'Gad 'tis well you came in Madam, I would have tryed what power that Witch would have, when I had drawn blood of her.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: What Witch, what does he talk of, the Witchcraft is within yonder—I tell ye, y'are all betray'd, Sir Charles has discover'd us.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A Hag, a Nightmare,—What's that you say Madam, discover'd, what's discover'd.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: We, we, all of us, some Devil or other has betray'd us, and discover'd all our design to Sir Charles, and the Doctor whom I overheard just now, threatning such unmerciful punishments to you and poor Numps there, that it almost distracted me to hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Ralph, Tom, and Christopher, and all the Servants of the House are call'd up for no good I fear, odswokers, look, look, see if that plaguy word will leave me now,—would I had never learn'd it.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, I find that I have h •… yet, only a sample of Cudgelling, the main payment is behind hand, I'm in a very pretty condition faith, but how could this be Madam, 'dsdeath, who is •… his Devil of a discoverer, what's his name.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: That, Sir Charles would not inform the Doctor, being as it seems enjoyn'd him as a secret, yet thus far told him, that it was an old Comrade of yours, and one of your own society.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Cunnington, as I live I find it now, it can be no Devil else—O, Son of a Whore! O, malicious Dog!

sp.speaker: Fulv
sp.p: But how he came to know it, that's Witchcraft agen.

sp.speaker: Marm
sp.p: Ods bodiki •… s, my heart misgives me, that I can best tell that, my Con •• rers name was Cunnington, who promis'd me a Dukedom for the secret 〈…〉 with a hundred Oaths to keep it, and sure a Conjurer has 〈…〉 to break his Oath, I must go and be better 〈…〉 as I'm a Christian.
〈…〉 meer jest, a Fool to all the Town and Country, 〈…〉 know, thrown into the Ho •… sepond.
〈…〉 some such thing, that's the 〈◊〉 on't.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: They do; nay, ten to one, or some worse punishment. Numps, prithee contrive something to help at a Pinch; what shall we do, hah?

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Why, truly my Lord de la Fool, if I might advise your good Lordship.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Pox on't, no jokes now, thou know'st 'tis honourable enough to assist Lovers, Numps.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Numps, Numps, what Numps, I'll be Numps no more not I, my Name's Gregory Golding an Ale-house-keeper here at Twitnam; 'oons, I shall have my Bones broke here about your Numps, and your honourable Lovers, would I were well out on't, 'odswokers, plague take that word too, would 'twere hang'd.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: I find Numps would hardly undertake me now folded up in a Letter.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Sdeath here they come, all contrivance is in vain too, I find I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: Nay, I am almost in as bad a Case, for I shall be tiez'd out of my Life, by Sir Charles and the young Blockhead now; but come, let's Act it to the last, my Lord, let's play our parts well however.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: A vengeance on't, I shall make a hopeful part of mine I believe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Charles, Guiacum, and Christopher.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Manage you your Daughter Sir Charles, whilst I confront this Rascal. Your Servant, my noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Is Mopsa come from the Black Stigian Fields, where yearly range the Cows of Proserpine, Tib, Whitehorn, Colly, Redrose, Smut, and Blincko; see where she sits stroking the swelling Teats, and takes Infernal Cream in Pails of Agate.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Rare counterfeiting Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How does my Daughter, do the Lovers tieze her still, where's the Reve end Mr. Tickletext, and the Worshipful Mr. Alderman Niggle, ha?

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: There, there he is, he shakes his Gold Chain at me, and pulls out his hair purse with fifty pieces, thinking to bribe my vertue, ah * I'll have none on't, ah * y' are an old Fellow, avaunt, avaunt, ah * ah *

sp.speaker: Sir Charl.
sp.p: Oh strange! why Doctor, she grows worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Extremely. ill Sir, I have been very much deceiv'd in her, I see now I must be forc'd to tye her in her Bed, and give her a Purge or two of Sand and Snow-water to abate this heat,—she shall take it to Night.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: The Devil shall have you first.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: And as for my Lord there, I see his fit Increases too, and I must be severe with him. Go, Christopher, get the Gives and Fetters ready, and call the rest of your Fellows as I order'd, tell the Surgeon too, I'll have the Skin of my Lords Head flead off, and rubb'd with Salt and Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Oh, Lord—

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: His Lordship has a wonderous hot Pate; I'll cool it with a Vengeance. You, Friend,
I think are somewhat craz'd too; but 'tis but slight. A good sound whipping three times round the Orchard will set you right, Numps.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Ah, no Numps, and't like your Worship, no Numps, I'm a poor, Twickenham Man, meerly drawn in as I hope to be sav'd.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: How does your Pulse beat now, my Lord, humph—do'e know me yet; am I a Devil, or a Recorder—Speak, I know your Cure is perfect.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why then, Faith, Doctor, I thank ye, I'm as well as ever I was in all my Life.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: And I too, Odswokers—agen—would the Devil had that word—

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But Fulvia there says nothing, her Distemper reigns still.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: No, Faith, now I think on't, I'm perfectly cur'd too;
Come, Sir Charles, and Doctor, 'tis but a Frolick, a Trial of Wit you see; hang't, pass it by for once, and give 'em their Liberty.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Not too fast, good Madam. Within there ho,
See these two well beaten, pump'd, and toss'd in a Blanket, for fear of a Relapse, and then discharge 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Let 'em be swing'd to purpose—go get you in, I'll speak with you anon.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sir Charles, what for a Trick of Wit? 'Twas but a Trick of Wit, Faith, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, your Wit is out of its Sphere now; and to set it right, I am obliged to cudgel ye by my Profession. Away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: This comes of Acting Numps, a Plague o'your Acting

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Farewell my good Lord de la Fool, Ha, ha ha—

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: 'Twas cunningly acted of the Rogues; but now, Sir Charles, what's to be done with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Keep her close up till you hear further from me: Take heed of Visitants, and more mad Lords, Doctor; I'll go and prepare her once more for my Son, and put the Case home to her, and her Ingratitude; it may be the Discovery of this Plot, and her small hopes of serving her own Humour, may make her yield to mine: But if she be stubborn,

lg.l: She shall have Cause to curse each tedious hour,
And know too late by me a Guardian's Power.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Quibble, Stockjobb, and Cunnington.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: COme, come, 'twas but a Joke, 'twas no more, Faith. Squire Thomas seems to be a very honest Gentleman, and a Lover of Business. Prethee Sir Quibble come in agen, and take t'other Glass, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: A scandalous Fellow to say I was an Hermaphrodite, to make a Monster, a Devil, I can't tell what of me, to disgrace me before the Ladies: But this shan't get the Heiress from me; I know his drift well enough, it shan't do I'll say't.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come, come, prethee, come in agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: 'Pray excuse me, Sir, I promis'd my Mother to come home to Supper; and I know her heart goes a pit a pat, if I'm never so little out of her sight, for fear I should be stole or come to any harm; besides I must tell ye plainly, I don't like the Company. I'll drink a Glass here with this honest Gentleman, if you please, but I would not come in agen for a 1000 l.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Well, my Comical Friend, do you entertain the Knight then, I must go mind my Guests within: Hey, bring some Wine there—

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: This is one of the silly Heiress stealers, of t'other side, I'll banter the Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir, by your Discourse within, Sir, I perceive that you are a great Traveller.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: I have seen I tink dis Globe, I mean Europe, Asie, Africk, Americk, or so; dat is all.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: That is all indeed, Sir, you must ride upon the Dogs-star, as the mad Song says, if you would see more.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Sire, I have seen much more, I have observe too de Globe Celestial; I have been so high as to hang my Hat upon one Horn of de Moon, and have toush de North-Pole vid min Finger.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: With your Finger, Sir, your Servant agen, Sir: Why that's very strange I'll say't.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Sir, I have live in de Moon-world some time, de Emperour is de ver proud Monarch, and keep de subject in great awe; de people dere are like de Pigmy, de man's and woman's not half yard high, but generally wise and ver great Politicians.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Ods diggers, this is a most excellent Fellow; and pray, Sir, don't those Politicians of the Moon take us English-Politicians for mad Fellows, hah?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Yes, truly, dey do tink dat you be all mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Prethee what Women are there? Do they dress their Heads as our Cocking Ladies do here, I wonder.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: No, no, de woman's dere have no head at all, de face stand vere de Breast should, and de Mouth is de Navel.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Oh, Lord, there must be strange kissing I'll say't.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: De Creation was ver wise in dat, no womans is suffer to have head dere, for fear she should plot Mischief.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I'll say't an admirable Reason too. But pray, Sir, now lets get down from the Moon a little; and since you have observed all the People and Cities in the World, pray, Sir, when was you last at London?

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Ven de Sun came last Post from de Antipodi dis morning, dis morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, very pretty agen, I'll say't: Why then, ten to one, but you have all the passages of the Town at your Finger's-ends; and, I'll say't, I long to hear 'em. Prethee what do they do at Court now, hah?

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Why de come, scrape, and look ver sharp, den whisper de friend in de corner, and talk politick one half hour, den oagle Repas du Roy, and make ver low Bow, den comb de Peruke, take Snuff, and scrape out agen; dat is all.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—that's very like a Courtier I'll say't▪ Come, come, now for the City, what are our Men of Gravity doing?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Why fait dey follow still dere old Custom—dat is, contrive to sheate one anoder; dey dat have no stock for Trade, make use of de stock of Impudence, and sign Policy to lay Wager, so make four, five sheating Bargain over night, and ver fairly break, and run away next morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Well said agen i' •… ackins; 'gad this is a plaguy sharp Fellow: But come now, for our Places of Diversion; Prethee how go Humours at the Musick-Meeting and Play-house?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p:
As for de humour amongst all de rest, I only observe tre sort, dat is, de 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 Coquet, and de F •… dler: de Beau dere make de fine Song, •… o shew his 〈…〉 s •… she admire de Beau, but laugh behind his back; de Fidler 〈…〉
•… usick, take de Money, and begar laugh at dem both.

sp.speaker: Sir Q—.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—Well I'll say't I'll give my Mother the slip some time or other, and go and see the Humours there I'm resolv'd; but come now, for the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Noting, noting; dere is noting dere pour Railery, but de Whore and de Critick, and two tre dozen of old musty Orange-Wench dat ride upon your Back while de Musiick play.

sp.speaker: Sir Q—.
sp.p: Odsdiggers, so they us'd to serve me, I'll say't: Well, but hark'e now, let's be a little serious;—I must know one thing more; heark'e, Do you ever go to Church—pray Friend?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Umph, Church!

sp.speaker: Sir Q—.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Do's Devotion thrive?—I know you must observe something of that too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: No fait, dere you pose me; for to speak truth, like good Christian, I have not see de inside of one Shurch dis—sixteen year, and begar I find de Town ver mush of my humour; de People and de Priest make de grand difference; he can say ver little or noting dat dey believe, and dey, Begar, vill do noting vat he advise; so I never trouble de Shurch at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Q—.
sp.p: I'll say't, an Admirable Persontoo! Well, dear Signior, you have so much oblig'd me, that if you please to come to my House, you shall find every day a Welcome that—

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Why Cunnington, Cunnington, what a Devil art Speaks entring. thou doing?

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Is your Name Cunnington, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Yes 'saith, Sir; But I know I shall be welcome to your House for all that Hah, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Hah, ha, ha,! What has the Hermaphrodite been banter'd agen? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: 'Slid there's some Trick in this; Odsdiggers, come near my house, and I'll set my Dogs at ye: A Plague, here comes more of 'em; I shall be laugh'd to Death if I stay. I'll say, 'oons Cunnington, I should bave been robb'd or ravish'd in a weeks time.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You came a little too soon; for I was just going to pump him about the Heiress.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Phoo, Pox she's secure enough Boy, but I have some fresh play in my head; now Stockjob's Wife, ye Rogue.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Here she comes, 'gad take me I'll give her my Billet deux presently.

div.stage: Enter Squeamish and Hotspur, and Mrs. Stockjob.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh horrid! Cousin, why d'e bring me into all this Company, especially where that Fellow is, for I am certainly inform'd, 'twas that horrid Fellow that writ the last Lampoon upon the Wells.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Have de patience Cousin, me shall find out dat presently, hark'e Sir, you damm English Pultroon, dare you abuse de Lady, dare you make de damm Lampoon ha?

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Not I Madam, you are the most mistaken in the World.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Not that I value the little malice, but to see the bestiality of the Fellow; I kept my self so reserv'd, Cousin, all this Summer to avoid censure, that I refus'd to receive visits from any Man under the Age of sixty nine, nor ever went any whither but to Church, and if they did not Lampoon me for that too, I'm no Christian.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: I must get the Rogue off,—'Gad take me, Madam, I have to Mrs. Stock job such a value for your Wit and Beauty, that upon my Honour, I would not deceive you in any thing, and I assure you he is innocent of the matter, therefore let me desire you to turn the discourse, I'll inform you more hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Ah Monsieur, 'tis impossible for me to doubt a Person of such merit, and so well accomplish'd as your self. Cousin, I am too Squeamish inform, by dis Gentleman, dat we are under de grand mistake.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: She inform'd by that Puppy, then they 're familiar I find.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon vid all mine heart, I understand you are de ver ingenious Person, and understand de Ladies affair.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Nay, I can't positively affirm he was the Person I confess; I only grounded my suspicion the more solidly, because of his Satyrical Phiz; O horrid! methinks his Face is a meer Lampoon it self.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come, come, slapdash, and so forth, let's reconcile all mistakes with a Glass of Wine and a Song, I've a Bowl of Punch ready within too.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: There spoke the Soul of the City and so forth, That was done now like a Man of intrigue.

div.stage: Puts a Note into Mrs. Stock job's bosom.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: My dear, dear Charmer, 'gad take me I've had a passion for ye above this six Months, and if you don't answer my Billet deux there, I shall dye that's certain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Dis is de ver agreable Fellow, but I must show de cunning, and not yield too soon,
—O, fye, fye, Monsieur, I am sure you mistake me I am not de Person, 'tis impossible dat I—

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Not the Person, by this dear hand, there's no Person in the World but you, has the power to charm my heart, your Eyes have made me a very.—

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: A very fop, Rascal, Dogbolt,—come, draw, draw, Buffoon, I'll teach you to be sawcy with Women in my Company.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Hey, slapdash, what a Plague's the matter now? keep the Peace there, hey day, is the Devil in ye all, and so forth.

div.stage: Fight here, and Tom Romance, and Shinken are beaten off, the Women shriek and run out.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Sir Quibble, Frederick and Quick witt.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Death, and Consusion, Cunnington, discover the Plot: Why how was it possible he should come to know it?

sp.speaker: Quic •…
sp.p: Nay that piece of Witchcraft I am yet to Conjure for, but I can assure you the beating was substantial, and so had the Blanket been too, if some of Sir Quibbles Gold, had not bribed off two of the Grooms: but come Si •… , take Heart, for though my Brains have taken occasion hitherto to disoblige my Bones a little; I have another Plot left yet, not only to make my revenge perfect upon Cunnington not; but to secure you the Lady, for since I have undertaken it, you shall have her, though the great Devil, and all his little Imps conspired against me.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p:
Pox, what vexes me most is, 'tis grown the Common Town talk already, they have it at the Coffee-house as familiar as the
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Prethee how didst do to Act the Madman? Ile say't, I'd have given a hundred Guineas to have seen thee a little; Prethee how didst look? and what didst say, I wonder? and when did the Lady come in with her Story? and which way, and upon what accompt? and wherefore?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: And wherefore good Sir come away quickly, and fetch the Guineas you promis'd, for I shall have occasion for a Bribe or too, to carryon the Affair: Farwell Sir, I see Company coming, stay.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Hah, am I fallen into this Satyrical Devils Clutches too, then I'm like to have a rare Breathing, for I perceive by that malicious Smile with which she mocks her self, that she has heard of this late business; and is as pleas'd I warrant, as prosperous Malice can make a Woman, when she has an opportunity of being reveng'd: Well, I am resolv'd to stand the brunt now, come what will on' •… , I see she's prepar'd for the Assault, and to beat her out of her Guard, Ile begin first. What always reading, Madam, still affronting Mankind, by Invading their Province of
Knowledge, •… ye, this is unnatural; a Lady should no more pretend to a Book, than a Sword, neither of 'em are proper for het Sphere of Activity.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: This, only excepted Sir, this is a Treatise proper for all degrees of People, 'tis call'd, Sir, an Hospital for Fools, where the most dislempe •… 'd of that sort shall be Cu •… 'd, or at least put into a good way. What think ye Sir, shall I send it ye, you may chance to have some apish humour in your Brain, or some foolish act in your Body, that may want a good remedy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Oh I thank ye, Madam, but must beg your Excuse, to take a Recipe from a Female Physi •… ian, to cure a defect in the Brain, that's a good one Faith: Why that's the way to make a Man stark Mad indeed: And as for my Body, I had as lieve take an old Purblind Country Nurse, if I had a mortal Bruise, or Palsie, and I were certain to have the scandal of a Cripple upon me all the days of my life after.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean by your Bruise, or Palsie; but considering your general distemper of Body, ' •… would be a greater scandal to the Nurse, to take ye in hand.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Very fine, well certainly there is not another so vain a thing in Nature, as a Woman that supposes her self a Wit; she fancies all the World must truckle to her Wit, and admire her Person, and Wit; tho the Wit's as Envious as a Witch, and often as Ugly.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That might be a fault indeed in the last Age; but in this I never met with any of your Town Crew, that have Wit enough to cause Envy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If there's any one, Fool enough to Love her, she'll make him a meer Changling, and like a little sullen Chit, of five years old, deny herself the Morsel she Loves; only to Teize and Vex another, when at the same time her mouth waters, and she's ready to starve for Hunger; this I think touches your Ladyships Copy-hold a little; but much good may't do ye with your sullen fit, I know you'l get a Husband, and a vast fortune by't.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Well Sir, not to be behind hand with ye, in your Frumps, much goood may do you with your Rich Heriess, you'l get a Wife, and a prodigious fortune by her, I hear too.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ah Curse on her, I find she knows all.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: For m •… part, it were unreasonable for me, to expect you to be constant to my s •… all merit, when you had such a tempting Lump as Fifty thousand Pounds to cherish your hopes withal; Fifty thousand Pounds, d'slife, there's ne're a Beau from Covent-Garden Church to the Tower of London, but shall give his little Corps to the Devil, every hour of the Day for't.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nor ne're a Lady that frequents the Park, Play-House, or the Musick-meeting; but shall marry a thing one degree remov'd from a Baboon for half as much.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: By which I find Sir, you are not out of hopes, I dare swear you think your self above one degree remov'd, tho your last Mad Plot upon the Heiress has given the world some strange suspitions to the Contrary: on m •… Conscience you'l return to me again Sir, you'l have some qualm or other come over ye shortly▪ then yet drunk, and with a kind of maudlin Repentance, come to beg my pardon,

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: So far from it, that I rather fear I shall have ye at my Lev •… e every morning shortly, with a pittiful Petition, imploring my Charity, to bes •… ow on •… e the remains of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.p:
The remains, Sir, I have Arithmetick enough to know, that take nothing from nothing, and there remains nothing: Besides a Married Town
Bea •… keeps always a Misers Table, there is so little for his own Family, that he'l never get thanks, or a blessing from any one that shall expect his remains, take that from me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Very well Madam, rally on, rally on, and enjoy your Wit. You have my free leave, whilst I Enjoy Fulvia, and fifty thousand Pounds, and so farewell; and, d'sdeath, such another full thrust and I were gone to all Intents and Purposes.

lg.l:
He's gone, and tears my Heart-strings as he goe •…
▪
Whilst I have only the poor Consolation
Of a feign'd Mirth, to hide my real Sorrow;
For still I Love this base ingrateful Wretch,
False as he is, and full of all the Mischiefs of his Sex.
I love him still, and have no Peace without Him;
But can I Love a Man that scorns my Love;
That poorly offers up Wit, Beauty, Merit,
Can I Love such a Man, and own it too;
No, I will rather Poyson, Stab, or Drown;
Revenge my self, on my unlucky self:
Do a thing Barbarous beyond my Sex.
Rather than this base Man shall know I Love him.
Eyes dry, dry your Tears, and keep the Secret in,
Whatever grief I feel, let none be seen,
Tho the strong Passion ne're so powerful grow,
Ile Choak with Love, rather than let him know.

div.head: Scene 1st.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: COme, Come Cousin, you must give me leave to tell ye, I understand an Intreague as well as an older Person, to let a young Hectorly Fellow, shew he ha so much command over ye, as to dare to quarrel, and expose ye in Company. Oh filthy, it shews a familiarity too sawcy for Civil Conversation; I hope Cousin you have not been particular with the Fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Vat you mean by dat Cousin, vat is particular.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh horrid, I hope you wont put me to the Fatigue of a Blush, by telling the Nauseous meaning, that were to deserve to be Lampoon'd indeed; when a Man is particular with a Woman, I think there is no great nead of a Sophister to explain the meaning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Vel, Vel, Pox take the particular, dat is all one, I assure you I have don vid him now, and vill encourage that fine young Gentleman, dat talk and •… ow, and rally so vel en Francois; me no endure de Huff de Bounce, de brutal way of Love no longer. Dear Monsieur Romance, is all French, all Talk, all Air, all Gallantry, and de oder Gentleman dat speak de Welch is ver fine person too, who I presume Cousin has de extream inclination to have de Intreague vid you.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: An Intreague with me, Oh filthy Fellow, that's a worser abuse than any has been yet put upon me, for he's the veriest Fop in Nature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Fop, Oh Mon deu! vat and worth twenty thousand Pounds, dats impossible! Oh, he is de ver fine Person, and has the greatest tender for you Cousin.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh fogh, I shall be Lampoon'd about him in a Weeks time, ile lay my Life on't: Oh horrid, ile go and l •… k my self up; But are you sure he's worth twenty thousand Pounds Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p:
Assurement▪
•… nd vill make good settlement, vich is ver much as times go.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: See here dey come vid Monsieur Stockjobb, who I have wheedle so, and make such great Fool, that he vill believe nothing against me vich my oder cast of Coxcomb say.

div.stage: Enter Stockjobb, Holspurr, T. Romance, Shinkin, and Singers with a Bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Stockj.
sp.p:
Come, Come, Let's have no brawling nor quarrelling, but sit down lovingly together, and help off with the Bowl, and so forth; what Pogry,
my Dear, my Fawn, my Pricket,—and my Cousin Siss •…
too; Hey, sla •…
dash, we'll all sit down too't Faith.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stockj.
sp.p: —Vat you please Dicky, ven de Husband Command de Wi •… e must alway be Obedient, dat is but Reason.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Ah subtle Witch.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: —Come Squire Thomas, and my Welsh Friend, Pray sit round▪ Here's some Honest Friends of mine will give us a Catch in three Parts▪ Cousin Sisse, Prithee sit down, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh horrid! Cousin, would you have me give such occasion to be Lampoon'd, as to sit drinking filthy Brandy amongst Men?

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Filthy Brandy; Twelve Shillings a Gallon, by this Hand, and will certainly be the best Commodity in the whole Kingdom shortly,—Harkee, Sisse, such another Word, and if there be a Lampoon to be got in Christendom, and so forth, I'll get one for thee.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: According to Shinkins Observations, this is not Prandy, look you, but Punch, which is fery goot to raise Ploods, and cause Plushes▪ and Pewtys in fair Ladies, look you, therefore pray you sit down, I pray you now.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Nay, Pray Sir,—Oh Lord,—Nay, if you will force me, What shall I do? I am so ashamed, well if I do, I'll swear I'll drink in my own Cup then,—Go, Ponade, and fetch it, it holds three quarters of a Spoonful just.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Dear Madam, Let me be happy with your sweet Hand

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Vat aile de Ruffian,—
—Monsieur, I am your most devoted.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: His most devoted, Oh rare Jilt, dee fleer Dog bold, I shall have your Nose anon.

div.stage: Enter Ponade, with a very little Cup.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come, Come, Slap-dash, No more grumbling Will, but take your Cup, and then let's have the Catch, and so forth.
Why, Cousin Sisse, What hast got there, an Acorn Cup? why a Flea may drink off that, prethee take one of ours, and so forth.

div.stage: Strikes the Cup out of her Hand.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh horrid, not for the World, the quantity of this is enough to suffocate my Spirits, as I am a Virgin.

div.stage: Hear a Catch, in three parts, in praise of Punch.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: By the Lord Mayor, very well perform'd Boys, Tholl, Loll, Loll, a •… dickins take it, it won't do now, yet I could have Sung my Sol, Fa, when I was a Batchelour purely Faith,—but these Wives, these Wives▪ spoil all our Parts; Come, Here's Prosperity to the City and Trade.

div.stage: Holspur rises up, and goes behind Mrs. Stockjob •… .

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: And as I was saying Madam.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: And as I was saying before Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stook.
sp.p:
Sir, I have nothing to say to you, you are strangely troublesom, To Hotspur.
Dat last agen, I beseech you Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Who leaves his Place there, Will. Hotspur, What a Plague dost stand brooding upon my Wi •… e there for, prithee come and take thy Cup, and let the Squire alone, he has business with her, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Business with her, Here's a damn'd Cuckoldly Son of a Whore, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: When her is in Wales, look you, her could drink very goot Metheglins with her Cousin Cadwallader, at the Three Red Herrings and C •… een Leeks in Mo •… mouth; but now since her saw you, her Heart has done nothing but thump, thump, and then her does sigh so sadly, Hey hoh, sighs. so that if her is obdurates and cruels, and will not love Shinkin, why then, alas, there is now way for her, look you, but Hey ho!

div.stage: Hotspur teizes Mrs. Stockjobb, she rises, and call out her Husband.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Love, Oh horrid! the very word is enough to fright me into an Apople •… y, would he would marry me, tho—as I'm a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: By this Hand, I believe I could make Monsieur lay forty Wager, and buy Stock every hour, if it were not for dat rude Fellow dat come and disturb us.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Sayst thou so, Slapdash, Gad if I had known that, he should have found this way to the Door before now, an uncivil Person to come to a Citizens Table and be well entertain'd, and yet ungratefully endeavour to hinder Business,—An idle Scoundrel, to stop the Sourse, the Life-blood of the City, Trade,—Gad I'll complain to my Lord Mayor immediately.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Now has that French Devil told some Lye or other of me, I'll lay my Life, Harkee Di •… k, art thou so very blind, as not to see thy self abused.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, Sir, I do see my self abused,—and so forth,—Sq •… ire Thomas, prithee come hither, Lookee, Pogry has inform'd me, ye are a very ingenious Person, and love Business, Lookee, what she does I'll stand to, therefore pray go and Discourse her, she's at your Service.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Oh Witall Coxcomb, what does he mean.

div.stage: Hotspur goes to hinder 'em, and Stockjobb interposes.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, no interruption.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: 'Dsdeath, to say publickly thy Wife's at his Service.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Upon the Score of Trade Sir, and so forth, I know what I do, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: The Devils grin at me, I have no Patience, Scoundrel, hands off.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Slapdash, hold her •… ast Squire Thomas, I give my Authority, why this is a breach both of our Charter and Customs; that a Citizen of London shan't have the Priviledge to dispose of his own Wife, for a Hectorly Fellow of t'other end of Town; Gad I'll complain to my Lord Mayor, the first thing I do.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: To take the Wife from the Husband, before his Face, is more than you can justifie, Williams, that is very true.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Thou art a •… ery Ass, Pox on thee for a crack'd Welch Harp, Hold your jarring, or—

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: No, No, I'll take a Course for this hereafter; In the mean time Pegry, since this rude Masterless Companion disturbs us here, my Chamber within is private, there you may settle Affairs, and so forth; Go, go in with her Squire Thomas, and because no body shall disturb ye, I'll lock ye up d •… see, and keep the Key my self.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, I shall run mad, why dolt, Madman, wilt thou lock her up with him too.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Upon the Score of Trade, and so forth, I'll show for once the Husbands Priviledge, without your leave Sir▪

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Trade, Ay there is a rare Trade going forward; Oh intollerable Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come Sir, you are a Scandalous t▪other end of Town Fellow, and my Lord Mayor shall know it; you shall know that a Citizen of London understands what's proper for Business: Cousin Sisse, take you your Gentleman into another Room; nay, nay, no Squeamish trick now, but go, since ye are molested here, I will have Business go forward in a place that's proper.—Go, go you after Sir, I'll be with ye anon.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Ay, ay, There's the Trade going forward too, this is Stockjobbing with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Pogry will draw her Fool into some devise or other, I am sure, and now I have finished this Affair so discreetly, I'll leave this Hector to chew the Cud by himself, and go and drink a Dish of Coffee with a good Neighbour, a Common Council-man, and Brother Stockjobber.

sp.speaker: Hotsp. Solus.
sp.p: A Curse on your City Understanding, and Destruction seize that Jilt, that tortures me with Love, tho I resolve to hate her,—damn'd infamous Creature, that Yesterday, as common as a Hireling, would have met my Appetite half way, and cherish'd it, now taken with a young pert noisie Coxcomb, deserts me without Blushing; but this senseless Wittall, her Husband, shall know, what a Snake he Fosters, before I have done with him.

lg.l: And whilst his City Iobbing he's pursuing▪
I'll shew him where▪s another Iobb a doing.

div.stage: Enter Quickwitt dressed like a Quaker, and Marmalet after him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, I think there's none of the Quaking Fraternity but will own I have mimick'd their Dress well, and play but thy part right Child, that we may revenge our selves upon this Cunning •… on that has so abused us, and th •… I may chance to be no Duke, I'll be a King to thee in my good will, my Love Child shall be beyond all Titles and Preferment.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Ah sweet Mr. Quickwit, the Rascal has asked my Pardon since, but I shall never forgive him for it; for, will you believe me, I have cryed about that Business till I have been as wet as if I had been dipp'd in a Pail of Water, to think that I should lift up my Hand against—

sp.speaker: Quick▪
sp.p: Well, well, 'tis all forgot.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: To dare Cudgel the Man that—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Well, well, 'twas all Accident, prethee no Tears.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: The Man I love so tenderly—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Enough, prithee enough,—I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: So tenderly, so very tenderly—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A Pox o'your Tenderness, There is no Plague under Heaven so tormenting as one of these old Cats, when she pretends to make Love; come, prithee no more of this Foolery Child, but let us go on with our Plot upon Cunnington; Let me see what's the Quakers Name that I'm to Act.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Zechiel, And't please ye Sir, my old Lord Fullworths Steward, my Mistresses Father.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Zechiel, very good, and one that you say has been trusted with all the Writings of her Estate.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: He has indeed, at whose House, Sir Charles (having found her as he thinks a little more pliant to his Sons Address) intends to meet her this Afternoon, to discourse about the Marriage, and to that purpose has given that Letter you have there to Cunnington to show the Doctor, who upon sight of it is to deliver my Lady to him, and a Note for fifty Guineas, which Sir Charles has ordered him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Then you are sure Cunningman has seen this Letter.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yes, An't please ye, and is merry beyond measure about his success of out witting you, he left it with me only whilst he is gone to disguise himself like a Quaker, for in no other Habit will Zechiel admit any one into his House, I expect him every Minute.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay, ay Child, Let him come now as soon as he pleases, we are prepared for him; and I think I am as much a Quaker as himself, or the Devil's in Iron Gray, the rest remains in thee to follow my Instructions, do but this Business neatly, and as for the other Business, thou worst of.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Ah Dear Sir, I swear you bring my Heart up to my very Mouth, I vow you do now, and I warrant ye Sir, for my part I▪ve my Cue perfectly.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: First then, instead of this Letter of Sir Charles, give him this of mine Child, to carry to the Doctor, 'tis sealed with a Wafer like it, and the Hand is Counterfeited, I'm sure, so exactly, 'tis impossible for him to discover that, then for the Contents let them operate at leisure.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: With all my Heart Sir, and I rejoice from my very Soul that I can do any thing to pleasure you, and be revenged of him; Hark, here he comes; away Sir to your Close •… , and when we go, be pleased to follow us, and you shall find me punctual to the least particular.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do it but Cunningly, and if thou art a Maid by to Morrow Night, why then say,—

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Ah sweet Sir, I understand ye to a Scruple, and Heaven bless ye; well I swear,—now my Hearts at my Mouth agen.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Hah, hah ha ha. I have been laughing at my self above this half hour, to see what a Figure I am; I have been Agent in a great many Intreagues in my life time, but never had any yet like this; this is a Masterpiece, a piece of Wit like Hains; for here have I insinuated my self so far into this grave Fool, Sr. Charles, by my subtle discovery of the late Affair; that he has trusted me in this Habit, to prepare the Old Quaker about the Writings, and aferwards to bring the Heiress her self to him—to him! Ha ha ha ha, there's the Jest now; and to receive as a Reward fifty Guinea's, ha ha ha! Alas poor shallow Knight! little does he think what's hatching in this Brain of mine: for, what will I do now? but instead of carrying her to him, keep her my self, and make her Marry me, or Compound swingeingly, which is all one; there's Wit now! ha ha ha, there's Mischief! Gad I love Mischief dearly: And when I have had her three or four Nights, let her hang me afterwards if she can, or any one else for me.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Come Sir, are ye ready? the Doctor's just gone home,—bless me, to see how Clothes will disguise one! Why? you look like a meer Ananias.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, don't I? Methinks I am filled with the out-goings of the over-flowing •… , of the Bowel-yernings, and for the humh, and hah!
Let me alone. Come give me the Letter, and be assur'd, tho' I Jok'd a litte the last time, yet I'le not fail to bring a better Business about, e're long for thee.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Well, well Sir; go and dispatch your own first.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: An Heiress, and fifty thousand Pounds! Gad I'm a lucky Dog, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Here's a rare Rogue for ye; had not I discovered the Plott, he had betrayed his Trust, and got the Heiress for himself; but as things go, will miss of his aim damnably: Now for my Quaking Faculty I must make one amongst 'em.

div.head: SCENE 2.

lg.l: Oh Love! How many strange, and different ways
Dost thou disturb the Quiet of our Minds?
If amongst all the Race of Male Deceivers,
With Curious search we chance to find out one,
That we can fancy Honest; some cross Doubt
Straight fills us, with a fear he may prove Haggard,
And then, Alas •… we split against a Rock.
That ruins us for ever: I dream •… last Night,
Frederick was False, Sordid and Mercenary:
And that he only lov'd me for my Fortune;
I give no credit to sleeps Idle Whimseys:
But yet it strangely troubles me—now Christopher.
VVhat Noise is that within?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: And 't please ye, some new Lunaticks last Night brought hither.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Prithee what are they.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: A spindle-legg'd French Taylor; That ever since the VVars, being at a loss how to get New Fashions for his whimsical Customers, Fatigu'd his Brain so much, that he grew craz'd upon it.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: VVhat, others?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: A superannated Maid of threescore and three; who being promised Marriage by a young Fellow of one and twenty, at the very Conceipt on't ran Mad for Joy.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Ala •… for her well who else?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: A Covent-Garden Beau, who being obliged to make a Song upon his Mistresses Paraquite, and sitting up three Days and three Nights, not being able to produce one tolerable Thought at the Conceipt of losing her Favour, lost the small remainder of his own Senses.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: So, what more?

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: A kept Miss, who being discarded by her resenting Lord, fell distracted, not for the loss of my Lord, but for her five pound a VVeek.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Go on.—

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.p: A Vintner whom his Customers had poisonned with making him taste his own VVine—besides a Quaker who is now coming▪ in here with my Master, of whom he'll give a better account himself.

div.stage: Enter Guiacum, with a Letter, Cunnington and Marmalett.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I hope Dr. you need no further satisfaction in the truth of my Commission; be pleas'd therefore to let the Lady get ready with all possible speed, and the Note too for the fifty Guinea's; I shall have present occasion for

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, I understand ye—Christopher—

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Christopher! what has Christopher to do in the Business? This is a strange, Old Formal Coxcomb: He cannot blow his Nose without his Man—Doctor, I must desire you to be as speedy as you can; for I've another part to act, as you may perceive by my Habit: And what a Character Sir Charles gives me, I suppose you find in the Letter.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; yes; he has given ye a notable Character: here indeed▪ Christopher, go presently, and bid the Barber come hither to shave his Head.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Your Servant Doctor; no Faith; that will be a Courtesy a little unseasonnable at present, by reason of my haste.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Alas, Poor Fellow! yet stay a little Christopher, where is his Master? Let him be call'd in First.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: My Master—

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: He is at the door an't please you; I'le go and fetch him; alas! I'le run Ten Miles on my bare Feet, to do the poor fellow any good.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Hey day! is she bewitched too? what a Plague do they mean? come, come Doctor, the Note quickly; and Madam Pray dispatch, I've a world of business to do, before Night yet.

sp.speaker: Fulv.
sp.p: 'Dslife! this is the most comical fellow, I ever saw.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p:
Oh! the dellirium is very strong upon him; d'e hear Christopher? bid your fellows make haste to strip him, and get ready the Canvass Shape, that he may have nothing to tear; and a pair of the strongest Fetters for his Leggs;
d'e hear? For Sir Charles informs me here, he is by fits very outragious.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Fits, and outragious? the Devil's in 'em all, sure: I know what's in the Letter well enough—come, come, this is no time for Jokes; Sir Charles will be impatient till the Lady comes, ye trifle, ye trifle, 'dsdeath! I should have bin with him by this time.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: This is a very Rogue, but Ile manage him presently.

sp.speaker: F •… lv.
sp.p: Here's like to be good sport if it holds.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: The Letter says too, he will be very Mischievous towards the Change o'th' Moon, which is this Evening, but that's no great matter, I can disable him from that by a good Whipping: He shall have 300 lashes upon the Belly▪

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: The Devil, I shall,—'dsheart how I tremble—nay, nay, if you pursue the Banter, and intend to affront Sir Charles, there's no more to be said, I must Inform him, and there's an end on't; But that Letter to my knowledge says otherwise: I'm sure I read it this Morning, the most sweet, Civil Complemental thing on my side that ever was penn'd.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: No doubt on't, Sir, no doubt on't: Can you read?

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Read; Ha, ha, ha! what a Pox does he take me for one of the Black-guard? This Coxcombly Doctor's craz'd himself, Ile be hang'd else—read! yes, yes, you shall find I can read,

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Doctor, 'tis proper that I let you know, I have made another discovery of a Plott, to carry off the Lady you have in Custody. This Rogue, that I send here with this Letter.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Go on, Sir, go on: I perceive you can read admirably, (being one of the Principal Contrivers,—this is VVitchcraft. 〈◊〉 believe my own Eyes.

sp.speaker: F •… via.
sp.p: Really as you say, Doctor; for a Crazed Person, the Man reads to a miracle.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: VVhat Craz'd Person, Madam? 'dsdeath! I shall run Mad indeed▪ if this trade hold.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Come Sir, to the next Paragraph.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: He was formerly a Sharper, and whither he be mad or no; I desire you to use him as such, for he's one of the greatest Rascalls in the whole VVorld,—as his Master will better inform thee:— 〈◊〉 my Mr. agen.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Sir Charles gives ye a notable Character, you see Sir.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: 'Dsheart Doctor! 'tis all Villany, Witchcraft, Cunjuration; I'm abus'd.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: The Fetters quickly, Christopher, he begins to •… ave, oh! here's his Master.

div.stage: Enter Quickquit Mimicking, a Quaker and Marmalett.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Death, and Hell! what Son of a Whore's this—I'm at my Witts end.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Come Friend, you must inform the Nature of his Madness, that I may Minister accordingly.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plainly, since that ungodly season, that I first perceived that the Spirit of truth was departed from him, I relinquish'd him, often seriously pondering upon his State of Reprobation, which plainly I find is worthy be Comiserted by all the Brethren and Sisters of the faithful.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p:
Oh! Rogue, I know him now,—Doctor y'are abus'd, Imposed
upon, trick'd, this is no more a Quaker then I am. This is an Arch Cheat this is—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Aw Satan, Satan! great, great, is thy power.

div.stage: Bawls in a loud Canting Tone.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: He Raves again, take hold of him, and stop his mouth there.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The Tempter is very powerful in him, he turneth and windeth him▪ which way he listeth, he goeth into his mouth like a Ratt, with a great Head and a long Tayle, and exalteth his voice within, in Curses and Exclamations hum! give me the Engine Woman with which we used to resist the Tempter.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Here 'tis an't please ye; put this into his mouth—and Satan can have no Power.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plainly, I have bin informed he hath bin trained up in the School of Sin vulgarly called the Play House, where the Devil Adorneth himself with toyes and trappings, where the Ears are misinformed and the Eyes misled, where the frail Son of Man caresieth the Woman inordinately, where he tempteth her to Midnight Gluttony; and whispereth into her unhallowed things.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: My Heart is ready to leap out to thee for Joy, for he do's it so Naturally 'tis impossible he should be discovered,—how the Fool the Doctor looks too?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Moreover, observe, how outragiously the old Draggon teareth him.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Ay, ay, tis time to begin,—away with him, and give him the Lashes I ordered.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plainly it behooveth thee Well, that the Spirit of Truth may once more return; and the old Man be rooted out,—now Rogue I think I'm even with thee——

div.stage: aside to—who kicks and strives to speak

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Aw—Satan, Satan, great is thy Power.
sp.stage: Bawls out aloud and is hurried out.
sp.p: But now, to the remaining part of my Charge, I am to Conduct a Woman from hence, a sinful Woman as it appeareth to me, who causeth with her transitory Wealth and Beauty, strange Appetites, Boylings and Fermentings in the Heart of Man.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Well Friend, no more enlarging upon that Subject; here is Sir Charles's Order in this Letter, who it seems is at a Garden-House here hard by; therefore Madam—you had best make haste; you need no disguise but your Masque, for he says there is a private back way to't which this honest Man has only knowledge of.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Plainly, thou sayest it.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Was there ever so admirable a Fellow? I'm scarce able to contain my self from laughing out.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Come, young VVoman, and let thy steps be guided soberly▪ Give me thy Carnal hand; hah! verily it is exceeding white, and hath an alluringness in the Palm thereof, which is, as it were, provoking: Hah! this is it now, which stroaketh the Forehead of Transgression till it become Masterless▪ and girdeth us into the Labyrinth of Misconstruction, from whence we seldom or never come forth our selves.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p:
What an odd sort of a Canting Rascall's this? and what a do's here with one Woman that has Mony? gad I've a Daughter of my own at home has sat pricking upon a clout at home this Seven Years, and no one has come to
her, but an Attorny's Clark, and City Groser; when this here is beset with all degrees, Ages and Religions—well, 'twill be always so; and where the Honny is, there will the Gnatts, Hyes, and Insects be buzzing together,—Christopher—my Cloak,—I'le take a little Air, and then see how—the Wedding goes forward.

div.head: SCENE 3.

sp.speaker: T, Rom.
sp.p: Gad take me, this was the most Comical adventure that ever the City was famous for, to lock us up with his Wife, and Neice upon the score of Trade: why? 'tis an Action ought to be known to Posterity and worthy to be Chronicled in the City Annalls.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Her Cousin Siss, was fery familliar too when her was alone; there was no pish, nor fye, nor pray be quiet, look you—only some little frowns and repukes, put fery kind looks for all that St. Davy.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: If I had not bin obliged to meet my Father here, I would not have left my little French woman this two hours, but he is so hot upon't to make me Marry this Heiresse, that he spoyles my humour of Intreaguing quite, gad take me.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Pray you see, where he comes yonder with the Lady that they call the crete Witt of Richmond, she that talks, and discourses, and Jeeres, and laughs, and makes Fools of all the Town by Cadwallader.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: By this Light, she's a rare Creature: 'dsheart I'm in Love with her up to the Ears already; why? she's finer than my little French Woman by half: ay Gad or my Lords Daughter either, or my Wife that is to be; or my Knights Lady at Cue; or Jenny in Lumbard Street; or my Widdows Daughter; or my Semstress, my Chambermaid or any of 'em: I'll write her a Bilet deux immediately, Gad take me.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Hey Gadsplutt! her will have more Women than the crete Turk has at this Rate, look you.

sp.speaker: Sr. Char.
sp.p: Yonder's my Son, Madam; and I am very glad to find you so well dispos'd, to the Marriage between him and your Kinswoman; for tho she has lately entertain'd some volatile Humours, which Youth may very well Excuse▪ Yet the Principall Verbs, her Wit and Vertue, so far counterpoise that.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Her Estate you mean, Sir Charles does so far Counterpoise that—

sp.speaker: S. Char.
sp.p: That the Candor of my Nature obliges me to dislike all other offers for him that are not possessed with her—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: With her—Land and Houses.

sp.speaker: Sr. Char.
sp.p: Good Qualities, Madam, having bin since my Noble Lords Death, her Father, a true honourer of her for her Extraction, merit and—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And Money; is not that a Principall Verb too, Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: A delicate Rogue; what an Air and Shape she has? Cousin, Rise prithee turn about a little.

div.stage:
takes out Pen, Ink and Paper, and writes on
•… hinkin's Back

sp.speaker: Sir. Char.
sp.p: Money, Madam! What the dirty Slave of our Conveniency? She has hit it to a hair, gad for all that; aside. can any Morall Man 〈◊〉 has his Reason, build his Content on such a Trifle.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
Oh Sir, take this from me, since the Golden Age, the World has lost those Moral Men you speak of: Money is now the Soul o'th Universe: The
States-man, Commoner, and Country-man, Phisitian, Lawyer, Cittizen, Priest, greedily dam their own for't every day; the man that's Rich must be accomplished too, his Apish Tricks are Gentleman like Carriage, his silly speeches called refind and Witty, if he be Prodigal they stile him generous, if Covetous, a close, wise wary fellow, if he detracts or Lyes, he's a fine Courtier, if Blasphemous, a Witt, if finnical a Beau, if drunk, he's then a merry Jolly Fellow, or if unmanly Lewd, a Rare Companion.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Ah that dear Sweet little Honey prating Tongue,—would I had it a little here, and if a stranger may have priviledge to affirm his passion; very good, gad take me.

div.stage: Read's his Paper, and writes again.

sp.speaker: Shink▪
sp.p: I pray you now Cousins make haste, for her has an Intreague too, look you, her has promised to meet her Cousin Siss, at seven Precisely.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: If Mony has these flourishing attributes Madam, what then must vertue have the chiefest good.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Faith, just, quite contrary, for vertue Sir is generally poor, and Poverty can give no Bribe for Praise, the virtuous Man that's poor, must be a Fool, a wretched sort of an uncurrant Coyn, that few or none will deal with; Tho he be wise, his best opinion is thought ignorance, his talk rediculous, his Person hated, he still fares worst, yet pays the dearest for it; has he a cause at Law? it shall be lost, has he a Claim in Love? he shall be Jilted, his Ingenuity is worse than Witchcraft, and every venial Error past forgiveness.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: And if I Love ye not better than both my Eyes, may I be poysoned like a Ratt at your Chamber door and be accompted the verriest Son of Whore in the World, instead of your most passionatly devoted most humble, and most obsequious Slave, Thomas Romance▪ gad take me, there I came off like an Angel.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: What a Devil is he making mouths at yonder, how now Tom what are you doing there?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: 'D •… life if he sees it I'm ruined; nothing Sr. I'm only casting up a Taylors Bill a little, that the Rogue mayn't cheat me.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: A Taylor's Bill, prithee leave of those trifles and prepare to entertain your Mistress whom I expect here instantly▪ with all you ought to thank this Lady too, her kinswoman, who gives ye her good liking.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Her good liking, gad, would I had it upon her own score; now what would I give that it were sealed? this were A Rare time to clap it into her hand.——

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That he has Sir. Charles, he may assure himself, or any one else so that Traitor Frederick be disappointed,—let me but frustrate his design and let the rest fall ou't, as fortune pleases.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Sir Charles here? they have dispatched their business very quickly I see.

sp.speaker: Sir. Char.
sp.p: Oh Doctor! welcome; y'are come in Admirable time, but where's my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: I hope she's not far of Sir, you are a better guardian than to trust her in ill hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Therefore, I recommended her to yours—where, where, is she?

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is fine merriment, why Sir? I desire to know, and whether she seems pleased since I sent—her to ye?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Sent her to me! 'dsdeath, what do's he mean.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Nay, what do you mean then? sye, sye, Sir Charles; am I a subject fit to make a Jest on?

sp.speaker: Sir. Char.
sp.p: Thou makest me Mad, to hear thy Ridling; I sent for her by Cunnington, dressed like a Quaker, who was to bring her to Old Zechiell, her Fathers Steward, where we have waited long, but no one came.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Why Sir? I gave her to that Quaker, and obeyed the orders in your Letter here, for Punishing the Impostor, that had contrived to Steal her.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Impostor, what Impostor? here's some Trick by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Read, Read the Letter, oh Confusion! how my Heart beats?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Trick'd, Ruin'd, Cheated, abus'd; this is none of my Letter, nor any of my orders; some subtil Devil has Counter-feited Cunnington, and on my life carried her off to Frederick.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Destruction seize the World; to Frederick did ye say, to Frederick?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: It must be so, he has doubtless given her to that other Cunning Rogue, and punished him▪ I sent for a feigned mischief.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: What e're has chanc'd is Fortunes fault not mine; that Quickwit is the Devil, and can Act in such variety of Shapes, Hell cannot balk his Cunning.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Very fine; so I perceive I am like to lose my Heiress again; but tis no great matter, for I've another new Intreague, and thats all one to me, gad take me.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Here is such Cousining, and Cheats, and Tricks, that Shinkin knows not what to make on't by St. Davy.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Torture and Death; this is the greatest Plague, the feinds could e're Invent to vex my Soul: he has her now and without doubt laughs at me.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Hey, mettle to the back too,—gad take me, Ile warrant her.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: The Fifty Guineas too, no doubt are paid by this time: this was a damn'd subtil Rogue.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay never hide thy self, take one good wish first; may thy dull resty Age increase diseases, the Palsy, Gout, Snattica, and Stone, and have no better Doctor than thy self, as for the Attributes of Fool and Cuckold, I need not grace thee with 'em; those thou hast already, but mayst thou have none but Saylers Wives for Patients, and those so Raving Mad that in their Fits each one may long to have a peice of thee, and Tear thee as the Thracians, once did Orpheus, or I could now, thou Paralitick insect.

div.stage: to Guiacum, shakes him by the Collar.
Enter Cunnington with a Quarterstaff, his Face all smutty, and he dressed in Canvass.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: O Villain! Dog, Doctor, are you there? I'll knock his Head off.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: More Mischief yet! I shall be murder'd now, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How, this! is't possible? What, my Friend Cunnington? nay if he were not an old Coxcomb, thou shouldest have thy penny-worths out of him; that's certain, for we perceive he deserves it richly; but prithee how gott'st thou off; I was just sending to thee.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p:
Why, as good luck would have it, just before they had time to Chain me, I made shift to climb up the Chimney; what kicks and Buffets I've endur'd for—you shall know at more leisure: I 〈◊〉 only now Breath and
time to tell ye, that if you follow me quickly, you may recover the Heiress agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Hah,—what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh thou blest Angel of a Fellow, go on.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: From the top of the Chimney, as I was trying to get down, casting my Eyes to a little Garden house, not far off, who should I see? but that Rogue in a Quakers habit, with Sir Quibble and Frederick leading your Daughter cross a Gravel Walk into an Arbor.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And hast thou marked the place, thou Charming Creature?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Most carefully.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Hah! and shall we get her? speak, speak, thou pretious▪

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: I tell ye, ye shall.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What from Frederick? hah! what sayst thou? speak quickly thou Cherubin.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Oons from Frederick? from all em: ye little Brisk pretty Black-ey'd—what a pox, will she Ravish me?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Thanks Fortune, that was unexpected.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Which you should never have known if I could have carried her off my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Let's away instantly and fetch the Constable and Watch; come, Tom, and Cousin.

sp.speaker: Soph,
sp.p: Oh Heaven! this is the happiest turn.

lg.l: For me it is upon a double Score,
I else had lost one Member, if no more.

div.head: SCENE. 4.
div.stage: Enter Sir Quibble, Fulvia, Dogget and Marmalett

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: This is the happiest moment of my Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: And mine too, I'll say't.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: That was a very close hugg; the Knight out does ye Sir Extreamly in his Carresses.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is not the Parson come yet? dull heavy fellow, how can he loyter so.

sp.speaker: Sir. Quib.
sp.p: Ay, what's his Name, pray Brother when is he to come, and what is he doing all this while.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Rid •… ulous questions! what shall I do with him Tom?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: I don't know the Fool begins to smell the Trick and grows Impertinent upon't.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: You must discover the truth to him, for he's so brisk upon me, theres no enduring him.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Why then, Madam? I'll say't, I believe you mistake your Man, this Gentleman is my Brother; Madam, 'tis I am your Knight; Madam, 'tis, I am he that is to do the favour.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: My Knight, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—her Knight! Oh fye Brother, you know your self and the Lady better sure.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Sir Quibble expresses himself very Comical in troth, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: Hey da, why what d'ee laugh at all so, and where's the Joak? I'll say't I can find none: Why, am not I to marry the Lady Mrs. Quickwit? and must not I be then her Knight?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, no, Sir Quibble there was another Design in't from the begining.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Alas Sir, what should you do with a Wife? when d'e think you should get her to be of your side? where would you find an Humour that would be suitable to ye? and why would you prove the Fatal Consequence of disagreeable Marriage, Sir; there's four questions, now answer me quickly.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—

div.stage: Sir Charles. T. Romance, Shink. Guiac. Constable.

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, hold your self contented a little; harkee Brother, han't I layd out a hundred and fifty Pounds about this business?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Within a small matter, I think; why sure you don't grutch to do a small kindness for your Brother?

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: No, but to part with ones Mistress to ones Brother, is a little too much, tho' I'll say't; therefore I must tell ye plainly, Brother, I won't do't.

sp.speaker: Quick▪
sp.p: You see the Lady is uneasie, Sir Quibble.

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis all one for that, keep you your distance too, or I'll say't I shall so tan your Quakers hide, I shall make ye act your Play but ill when you come to't agen else; why sure? tho' I have bin led by the Nose a little, and laid out my Money, I can't tell how, I won't lose my Mrs.—ye Lobrocks what a Plague I am not such a Fool neither?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: If this blunt Fool should beat us both now, 'twould be a pretty jest?

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Nay then, there's no time for delays; let go her hand and presently, or I'll run my Sword into your Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: Why then, I'le run mine into your gutts; let go my Mistress: No I an't such a Fool neither I tell ye: Odzooks I'le keep her in spite of ye, hoh hoh.

div.stage: He prepares to fight awkerdly, then Enter Sir Charles, T. Romance, Shinkin Guiacum—Sophronia with Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Will ye so, Sir? that's more than you can promise long, and so have at ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Quibb.
sp.p: Nay then, stand to't Brother; I'me of thy side agen now, I'll say' •… .

div.stage: Fight here, and Fredericks Party is beaten off then. Reenter Sir Charles, T. Rom. Shinkin with his Head broke; Guiac. Cunnington, Sophronia, Constable and Watch with Fulvia retaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles.
sp.p: So, you are ours once agen, in spite of Fortune. How now Cousin, what Wounded?

sp.speaker: Shink
sp.p: A Plague take your Confounded English Customs, look you, that you cannot get your Wives and your Marriages, but a Shentleman must have his Pate and his Prains peaten out about it? well fare her own Countrey I say, the Prittains have not such Pribbles and Prabbles, and broken Pates by Cadwallader.

lg.l: When any Prittain pargains for his Spouse;
He prings so many Seep, so many Cows:
The Pridegroom tells the Pride his Loves intent,
And she kind Fool as quickly gives Consent.
No Swords, Cads plutt, nor Cudgells there prevails;
But kiss and Couple, thats the Way in Wales.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: HAD ever Man such Cause to Curse his Fortune? to be so neer the long'd for happiness, and then to lose it, doubles the vexation: Oh I could ou •… rail now a losing Gamester; a •… ashier'd Captain; or a Grumbler double Tax'd.

sp.speaker: Quick▪
sp.p: And I, a Suburb Bawd just come from Garting: A Plague of my Quakers shape here; if I had not look'd so like a Rogue, on my Conscience I had thriven better.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: I'm sure my loss is irrecoverable, for I must ne▪re hope to come into Favour with Sir Charles agen, but then the Consolation I have in your sweet promise, Sir, does I confess allay—

sp.speaker: Quick.
