sp.p: O prithee good Spouse that must be; no more Love now, my Bones smart a little too▪ much at present, to let me entertain any Amorous▪ Motions—Ah Plague of their Rusty Bills; that Rogue Cunningman took care they should all fall on me still; but what's most Comical? As I was running off after you, he comes up to me and with a grave Face, as if he had known nothing of the matter, invites me to drink a stand of Ale with him this Evening at Numpses.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha—and wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay by this Light will I; and if I can mould that dull headed Fellow once more rightly, my Witty Antagonist shall have but little cause to boast his late success—come Courage, Sir; they shall make Paste of my Bones with their Battoons e're I give up a Cause I've undertaken, whilst my Brains lye in their right place: This Evening will prove all, till then farewell—If I get the Dice once on my side—the Golds my own yet; I've Art enough to manage them I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: I must follow him and put him once more in mind.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: If Fulvia were Heiress apparent to the Universe, there could not be more Wit nor diligence us'd obout her. This is the third time our Confederate Forces have been repuls'd: And Faith were I not sensible the Castle were stor'd: with the best sort of Ammunition, tempting Gold? I think I should have long since raised the Siege: I must confess my self to be of that Pagan Opinion, that there is no one Quality belonging to a Woman, unless it be her Money that can countervail a Man's playing the Fool in Courting her a Month for: This was my Plea with Sophronia once, who has some simple passionate Papers of mine still, that I wish I had out of her hands; my deserting was not so very just its true, but then 'twas very profitable, and this damn'd Money has power to make a Rogue of a Man, often times Constancy, that's most certain?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay if you'r in a Passion, I'll desist, but if you'll hear, I'll prove it?

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: What, that Frederick's false! Oh 'tis ridiculous Mallice, and I'll not believe it: I know she lov'd him her self once, and this is now the product of her Poph.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: False as Brieno to Olimpia in the Story, base, Mercenary, the worst degree of Falsehood.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Ha ha, ha, ha! you rave, you rave, Cousin; I pitty ye; pray go home and let blood, you are dangerously distemper'd take my word.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Not with thy Disease, Child, I'm sure; I swear I would not have it for the World.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: You talk as if I had the Gout or Palsie, or a long Family Rhumatism, that distinguish'd the Blood of my Relations for ten Ages: VVhat Diseease is't you mean—take heed of Scandel Cousin?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nay, do you take heed on't Cousin? for the Disease that I mean, has generally some Infection that way, 'tis called a Masculine Calenture, or the Plague of Man-loving; it often seizes upon. Creatures of thy Age, and is of that strange Nature, that it dulls and Numbs the Brains as if they were froze, which must be chas'd and warmed a long time by Reason and Argument, or else the Patient will never return to her right Senses.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Lord, that's a terrible Disease indeed, but yet for all its violence, I have Brains enough left to see a distemper in you too, Cousin; 'tis the Plague of Greediness, and you use me as the great Sister in a Country Cottage does the lesser; you would pack me to Bed without any Supper, because you have a mind to my Bread and Butter.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No, no, Child, the Case differs between us extreamly, some may feast with a Rasher upon the Coals, whilst others •… eck at the very smell: And I must have thy Stomach before I can be greedy of thy Dyet.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Come, come, Cousin, you have stomach enough, nay indeed so much that you grow sullen with it, and like a little Child, won't eat your Meal till you see the Plate ready to be given away to another; for as homely a bit as you make of that Rasher, if I am mot mistaken in the Morsel, you would be glad of it to relish your Mornings Draught, and for all your Course Name of Rasher, tartly think it a Gnatt or a VVheat-Ear.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If Frederick be the Wheat-Ear you mean? I had rather have an Old Caoon at the latter end of Iuly.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Ah, you shall never banter me with that—you'd think him a young Pheasant at the latter end of October, if you had him, to my knowledge?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I think him, prithee if his Spesies were chnaged, and he were turned into a Cormorant, a Buzzard, or an Owl, 'twere all one to me.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Any thing but the Capon, Cousin, you were speaking of, I dare swear for all your Anger, you have too much Charity, to wish him turned into that.

sp.speaker: Sophr.
sp.p: It does so little concern my Charity, that I should like my Hen with Eggs very well without any trouble, to know they should never come to be Chickens, and consequently Cocks of the Game. Besides there is so much ill Blood begot now a days, and so many Strains Crossed, that if, for the Future, the Sex were all Capons, •… question whether the King would lose e're a good Subject by't.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: This is your Satyricall Vein now. Oh! how you Fatten your self with this humour, just like a Noncon, that rails at Episcopacy, not or any just reason, but through self will'd Opinion, and rediculous Envy; else why is Frederick still the Theam of Railing?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh! thou ungrateful Creature, have I not told thee? 'tis through kindness to thee.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: To me, rather say through Hatred to him, because he Loves me▪

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: He Loves thee not, his baseness does deceave thee; Mercenary Soul Covets thy Fortune; thy Person is the least of all his wishes.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Just so I dream't indeed aside but 'tis▪ Barbarity to doubt a Lover for an Idle dream; I'll not be so unjust, come, come, 'tis all Envy; and to deal freely with ye, I now must tell ye, I take it as an affront, not as a kindness.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That's always a Fools humour, when they have not Brains enough to know the Courtesy, they term it an Affront.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Well, for all your mighty Wit, this shall not get your Ends; I see your Hatred and your Envy to him, and consequently judge his Love to me: I'll Marry him in spite of all the World.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Thou shalt not Marry him, tho all the World assist thee.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: How poor is this, and mean, because my merit appears above those in his deserving Eyes; thy Heart breeds venom, and thy Slaundrous Tongue, dissention between Lovers.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Lovers! Damnation, how She Tortures me? I tell thee once more thou deceived poor Creature; he does not Love thee, nor cannot Marry thee if he would, which is a secret; nothing but sweet revenge could e're draw from me.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: What, will you Cunjure? shall your plain dealing Faculty Convert it self to Magick? or d'ee carry a little Familiar under your Girdle, to Enchant us upon occasion; which way will you do this?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: That e're the Clock sound Midnight thou▪ shalt know; in the mean time, let thy Young Hotbrain'd wild unthinking Head remember this from me.

lg.l: Love may seem great, that in its self is small;
Looks cover thoughts and interest governs all:
When Damon to an Heiress speaks kind things,
'Tis not for what she is, but what she brings.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: She has so much moved the passion in my Soul, my Eyes can scarce contain it? what discovery she can make, I know not, but long to be resolved; tis true, we have had so many lets and troubles in this business; as if Providence it self dislik'd the proceedings; but still this is no proof; besides he has Sworn his faithful Love so often, 'twere infamous and dishonourable to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles.
sp.p: Madam, I need not tell you my resentments, nor how I rellish your ungenerous dealings; you have reason enough to guess, and after guessing, have wit enough to make me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Well, Sir Charles, consideration you know, ne're comes too late.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles.
sp.p: Right, Madam, and to shew you that I practice it my self, I will forget your late Discoveries, and once more address my self, an humble Suitor on my Sons behalf.

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: I will consider of it, mean time, believe this fairness of your Temper wins me more, then all your plots and Stratagems before.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come, come; Slapdash, twill be a Match faith, and so forth; gad I'll say this for Squire Thomas, he's a Notable person, as my wife informs me; she says he pushes forward into business mighty well; he'll be a great incourager of Trade, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles.
sp.p:
I hope my Cander and my Love at last, will force ye to be gratefull, and to shew how much I prize a Reconcilement; this Night we will have
Revells and a Ball, and I my self will drink one Glass the more, in honour of the Marriage▪

sp.speaker: Fulvia
sp.p: Marriage, Sir, is a thing of weight; but as I told ye, Sir, I will consider of it, and to that purpose begg the favour to retire a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Charles.
sp.p: Do so, and rest your self against the Evening, for Tom intends to lead ye a brisk measure i'faith—so I hope all will be right now, she seems considerative, which is one great step to Sentiment and Knowledge

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Pugh! Slapdash, the woman has it in her head; now Sir Charles, all will go well I see't.

sp.speaker: Hots.
sp.p: Now Sir, if you have any regard to your Honour, or the Reputation of a Citizen of London, as you have formerly flourished upon, come along with me, and you shall see what a Snake you have foster'd up; or to speak in plainer Terms, you shall see what a Cuckold you are.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Come, y'are a rude Hectorly to'ther end of Town fellow, I tell ye •… pray keep from my House: I a Cuckold because I promote business, and Mannage my Wife wisely for the honour of the City; Sir, I scorn your words, for Gadzookes, I had rather be an Elephant.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: But in the mean time, you are a Beast of another kind, which come but along with me, shall appeare; I will shew thee such things, such Monstrous things.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: What you have seen Squire Thomas I warrant, go into my Wives Chamber privately, or so; well what then? tis about business and so forth, she knows what she does I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Ay, but you don't know what she does to my knowledg; come, come▪ you shall go, I have lodged 'em all yonder, the Welsh Fop, and his Skittish Devil too; your Rooms are all taken up and managed for the honour of the City, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Why then they are managed according to my desire, and so forth. I defy any Citizens Wife within the Wails, to have a better head for business than her self; for I'll hold a Hundred Pounds, she has drawn one of 'em into some lucky wager or other; nay, nay, prithee hold thy tongue; gad, if thou wer't one of the Apostles, I'de believe nothing against Pogry and Squire Thomas, not I

sp.speaker: Hots.
sp.p: Why then like an unbelieving Sotas thou art, come and use thy Eyes▪ nay, nay, no drawing back—by Heaven thou shalt go.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: To laugh at thee, which I know I shall do and Damnably too, I a Cuckold,—as I said before I shall soon be an Elephant I'm sure.

div.head: SCENE. 3.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p:
Well, I believe I am an Orginal about Intreague; I don't think there's the fellow of me in Europe; gad take me, for now is my Father thumping his Brains, and plotting to get this Heress for me, and here am I hunting about
for Sophronia, upon another Intreague: I conveyed a Letter to her just now, by putting it into the Service Book at Church, then dogg'd her home hither,—I must find her out, for I long to know the success on't.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Well, Shinkins was not much behind her in Intreagues, neither look you, for her Cousin Siss, was hide her self hereabouts too, who I find loves Corners and py places extreamly, where gadsplut if Shinkin can find her, her will put her toot, for corners and py places are fery full of temptation; but for all her putting toot, there shall be no Marriages in the Case by St. Davy, there her will peg her Pardon.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Why, that's spoke like a Man of Intreague, gad take me, would I had my dear Angel here, that I am looking for in a Corner.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Softly, softly, take care they don't see ye, shees gon I find at present, but I know will soon return; in the mean time, pray observe the Dialogue between these two Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: I shall observe to laugh at you Egregiously, that I shall and so forth.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Pogry stays so long that I see I must leave her, and go and seek out my new Charmer.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Pogry—de' •… hear, Sir, he begins already.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Well Tom Fool, what o' that?

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Fye, fye, to desert your intreague so soon, was to shew falshoods and inconstancies, which is not like Man of honours, look you.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: 'Tis intreague, pray mind that Hint too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Jackanapes, what hint, ye Ass you, what Hint?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Pox on't, her over fondness every day tries me more then a Match at Tennis; here's a Locket she gave me this Morning, which it seems the Fool her Husband gave her Yesterday.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Humph,—humph.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: A trifle worth about Fifty Pounds I believe, she teizes me with such Follies as these every minute almost.

sp.speaker: Hosp.
sp.p: Lookee, Sir, so much for the incouragement of Trade, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: By the Lord Major, the very Lockett that I had of Sir Paul Poundage, the Goldsmith, to let him have share in my Project of the Catskin, oh! I am confounded, I cannot believe my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Nay, pray Sir don't laugh too extravagantly, Squire Tomas is but opening the Jest yet.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: But the jest best is, the Cuckold admits me into his Wives Chamber every day, in hopes she will draw me in to lay wagers; when, gad take, me, the only one that ever laid or intend to lay, was a Brass Shilling against a good one, that her next Kid will be a Boy.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: There Sir, what think, e of that wager too, has she not drawn him in rarely?

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Oh Villian! tother End of Town Bully to ruin business too, that's worse then all; gad I'll speak to my Cousin Touchhole, a Captain of the Trainbands, to lend me a File of Musquetteers to Shoot the Rampant Dog through the Belly.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Nay, nay, have patience Dick, and don't hinder Trade I say.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Trade, gadzooks, this is the Devil of a Trade.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Theres a light in the next Room, and ten to one Sophronia's there a lone, gad I'll go and see, Cloak and Hat lye you there; if Pogry comes in the mean time, let her stay, I have her so much at command, she dares not be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Shinkin.
sp.p: Flimms and Flams, and put her toot,—hey Slapdash, why, this is Bawdy-house fashion right, the Welshman's gon to tickle my Cousin Siss in the next Room too.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Ay that's all one, 'tis all to promote Trade you know, and for the honour of the City.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Oh Confusion to the City and all Trade, if this be the Fruits of wagering and stockjobbing, I have no Patience: I'll go to my Cousin Touch-hole, immediately: I'll have a dozen Musquets at least.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Nay Faith, stay and see all now, for here's the good Wife coming through the Garden, and here's the Eopps Cloak and Hat left as opportunely to disguise thee, as if we had contrived it; here, here, on with it quickly and Practice his affected Gate, I warrant, you make some strange Discovery.

div.stage: Stock. puts on his Cloak and Hat.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Na, like enough, but gad I'll send her home agen; if I do, she shall ship for Piccardy with the Next Wind—A Cuckold, Oons I had rather be an Elephant by half; but this comes of succouring French Refugees, with a Pox to 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Ah dear Monsieur, I beg your Pardon vid all min Heart, dat I stay so long, but now I speak of mine Heart dat has bin vid you all dis while, and I only stay to take de Convenience of de Fool my Husbands being out of de way, to bring off some small trifles of Gold and Jewels, which are dedicate to de Joy of my Soul, my Hearts Blood, my Treasure.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Slap dash, here's a French Devil for ye and so forth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Stock.
sp.p: I am so fatigu'd vid dat Brute, dat I can have patience no longer, and derefore come to trow my self upon you, vid whom I will henceforth live and dye, and whom I will follow all de World over.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Why? well said Pogry, rarely done, Pogry, go and be hang'd Pogry, good Protestant Refugee, to Piccardy go, but the Gold and Jewels shall stay in England, ye Jade.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Oh Diable, vat dam misfortune is this?

sp.speaker: Hots.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, Madam, I know your Interest with Dicky, will turn the Scale immediatly; this is all upon the score of Trade.

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Oh Confound all Trade, Burn the Exchange, hang up all Wagerers and Stockjobbers, and the Devil take all business out of my doors, ye Whore; you are a Protestant, are ye?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Gad take me, I had like to have made a damn'n mistake yonder, for instead of Sophronia, who should I meet within there, but my Father and the Heiress, whom he has just carried to his own House, and Commanded me to follow—Hah, Dicky! how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p:
Why Dicky does wondrous well, Sir, as well as a Cuckold can Sir, that had rather be an Elephant there; there's Pogry too, go, go, manage your Trade
together, lay another brass Shilling to a Copper one; Stockjob lay Wagers and be damn'd together, honest Squire Thomas, and I'le go to my Cousin Touchhole and get you mawl'd, Dogbolt, if I can, for all that, and so farewell t'e.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: So now you may launch to Piccardy agen, and follow your old Trade of Basketmaking, Jilt; I think I have spoyl'd your Market pretty well here; for your part Coxcomb, I'll go and inform your Father of your design upon Sophronia, that I think will do your business too.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: 'Dsdeath if he does that, I'm undone for ever, I must after and prevent it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Ah! dear Monsieur will you leave me then?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Leave thee, ay gad if thou wert a Cherubin, and I think that's a Station remote enough for a French Refuge

sp.speaker: Mrs. Stock.
sp.p: Vas ever hopeful Intreague so spoyl'd—diable must me go Weeps to France agen too, by dis hand me vill deny dat, me vill Rob, me vill Pick de Pocket, me vill drown, me vill hang before ever me leave Sweet England, to go into France agen, dat is certain.

div.head: SCENE 4th.
div.stage: Cunningman and Quickwit Smoaking at a Table, with a Stand of Ale.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Come all malice apart, prithee lets be grave no longer, but drown Animosities in the bottom of the Pitcher; thou'rt an Ingenious Fellow, and I've a mind to be reconciled to thee, and therefore contrived to meet at this Little Cottage out of the way, where we may speak our minds freely,—Come give me thy hand, shall we be friends?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Prithee, thou canst not be a friend to any Body.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I know thou'rt angry, but faith Tom I could not help it, thou knowest tis naturall to me to Love Mischief.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Come pull away then.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.p: Come Faith the Heiress health, let's remember her that we have had all this busle about; ye witty Rogue you, I'm damnably afraid you'l get her from us agen, for all her Guardian has her so fast.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Very well Sir, insult, insult; you have the Dice, you may do what you please, ha, ha, ha, gad I should lose another Brace of Fifties if thou shouldst, but I think I may venture her this once.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Ay, Pox on ye for a Witty Rogue, you have the better of me clearly, my Brains are quite dull'd.

sp.speaker: Cunn.
sp.p: Then not to banter any longer, the Match betwixt young Romance is made up, and we are to have a Ball at Sir Charles's House immediately: I wait here for some Masquerading Habits, that I have sent a Messenger to borrow at Twickenham; there's to be a little Ataque too of Pluto, Orpheus, and Euridice, of my Composing, and the Musick of Mr. Purcels—here's the Design, I'll shew it thee.

sp.speaker: Quickwitt.
sp.p: Ay hang ye, you us'd to be Ingenious enough at these things.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: There's a Man without, with a Bundle, desires to speak with ye, and 't shall please ye.—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! that's well, 'tis the Fellow with the Habits, I must go and take 'em.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Ah Master Quickwit, Numps was a damn'd sower part for me, it was adswowkers, but d'e hear, when am I to be paid for't, I was only thrash'd confoundedly for acting so well,—that's all I have got yet.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why now the happy Minute's come to make ample satisfaction to us both, and do but as I advise thee, thou shalt get thy Twenty Pounds presently, and Mr. Frederick shall have the Heiress into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Odswowkers, how can that be, Master Quickwit?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Do'st know this Fellow that went out?

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Not I, I never saw him in my life.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This is that very Rogue that betray'd us to Sir Charles, and the Doctor, that procur'd thy beating, and has ever since frustrated our Plots upon the Heiress.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: 'Sbud, my Bones ake at the very thought on't; oh Dog Villain, is this he?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: This is the very Rascal, who is now gone out for some disguises to make some Dancing Entertainment there this Evening; now if thou can'st but get two or three of thy honest Neighbours to seize him, I'll contrive the Heiress for Frederick and he shall have the Guinnies ready for thee.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: 'Odzookes Master Quickwit, I'll do it immediately, for it never could happen in a better time, for I have three or four Neighbours here drinking in the next Room, that will do't for Mr. Frederick at a words speaking.—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Away then dear Numps, and call 'em instantly,—now Fortune favour this once, and be my Goddess for ever after.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Well, prithee tell me now, how do'st like the contrivance, you must know I am to do Pluto there my self.

sp.speaker: Quick▪
sp.p: Nay, thou art the fittest Person to act the Devil, of any one I know, that I'll say for thee.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, prithee leave off thy frumps, thou can'st not forgive me heartily yet, I see, come faith, give me thy Hand, I'll contract a Friendship with thee.

sp.speaker: Quick▪
sp.p: Ay, that's likely to prove well, why, thou never yet could'st be a Friend to thy self, much less to any one else.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Faith, the Heiress and I will drink thy health presently, but you shall promise me, you won't get her from me agen, you witty Rascal—you shall faith, ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: W'are Catchpol'd Ioe—I'll promise nothing.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: How now, what a Devil's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you must go along with us.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: With you, whither, forwhat—'Oons are the Men mad?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Alas, good Sir, why de'ye pull and haul the Gentleman so, 'Dshart, what's the matter I say, what have I done?

sp.speaker: 1 Count.
sp.p: What has he done Brother? By the Maskins I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Tell him he has spoke Treasonable words against the Government.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Secure him as a Traytor, he has spoke some vengenable words—against the Government.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Who I, 'dsdeath, I?

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Oh, Rogue, Villain, has he so, we'll hamper ye.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: A Traytor, nay then there may be Treason in this bundle for ought I know, I'll secure that.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Sbud I have said nothing, ye are all mad sure, I tell ye you mistake your Man,—Brother, prithee put in a word for me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: No, Brother, no, Treason's a dangerous thing, I dare not meddle in't.

sp.speaker: Numps.
sp.p: Come, come, away with him to Mr. Soakes the Constables, and then let him deal with him.

sp.speaker: 2 Count.
sp.p: Ay, ay, away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Pray remember to drink my Health with the Heiress, good Brother.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Away with him, Gentlemen, away with him, ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ah, plague upon ye, help, help, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: So, now I'll to Frederick immediately—the Dice are now on my side—and if I don't thrive now by my Hand, I shall despair hereafter.

div.head: SCENE Ultima.
div.stage: Enter Sir Charles and Guiasum, Hotspurr, and T. Romance.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: You'll be sure to keep your promise.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Punctually, keep but my Counsel, and Five Hundred Pounds are thine at the day of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Well, Sir, upon that condition my Mouth is seal'd up, and your Father shall know nothing, but if you abuse my trust, Bilbo's the word, you know what I mean.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Well, well, not a word more, this plaguy hot-headed Fellow,—may do me mischief now, but when I'me once Married, I'll mannage him as I see occasion.—

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Since Fredericks ill fortune has made him lose the Heiress, 'tis some part of Revenge, to make this Fool pay soundly for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Come, where are the Musick and the Dancers,—Son Tom, why methinks thou art lazy in the business.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Mr. Cunnington is not come yet, Sir, with the Habits, but we expect him every Minute; gad take me, my head runs so much upon Sophronia, that I can get nothing else into't for the heart o'me.

sp.speaker: Guias.
sp.p: Well, I am glad to see things in so good a posture at last, by the life of Gallen, all great advantages are acquired with great trouble—she's an Heiress and Rich, the more difficult still to be obtain'd, but—Patience and Industry make all things easie; I forgive her trick upon me with all my Heart, and shall be well pleas'd to Tope a Bumper at her Wedding.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Hotspurr, y'are welcome, I see my Son and you are reconcil'd, and honourably I make no question, therefore shall be glad to appear your Friend.

sp.speaker: Hotsp.
sp.p: Friend, ay, just as the Friendship of the World is, he cares not Threepence if I were Strapado'd; nor I three Farthings if he were Hang'd.—

div.stage: Enter Shinkin, and Squeamish with a Paper.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Oh horrid! to infringe your Word and Honour, is a baseness not proper for a Gentleman, and I'll discover it to your Uncle, as I'me a Virgin.—

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: And Gadsplut, to Marry Wildcats, and Harridans, and her knows not what, is like Fools by St. Davy, and her will discover that too.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How now, what's the matter, Cousin Rice, what is't occasions the Lady's tears.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Sir Charles, tho' I confess the odious story ought to be conceal'd, but since my▪ Honour is concern'd, it must out.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: For now we shall hear a Welsh Intrigue, gad take me, I shall bring a new method on't by degrees, in all the Countys about England.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: You all know my detestation of Lampoons, and the care I have always taken, to prevent 'em, but you must know, this Gentleman, having long made an honourable Address of Love to me▪ upon condition that he defended me against scandal by Marriage,—at last I consented.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: Gadsplut her only talk'd of Marriages, look you to keep her from squeaking and squawling, her intentions were quite other things by Cadway.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—Madam, to my knowledge, my Cousin Rice hates Marriage, as much as you do a Lampoon, you are mistaken in your Man—gad take me.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: The more reprobate Person he, for Heaven knows, Sir Charles, how loth I was to Intriegue with any Man, and to that purpose, have often ran up into my Chamber, got into dark Closets, Cellars, Larders, and such by-places, where I thought the mischief of Man, could not overtake me, as I'me a Virgin.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Where you thought the mischief of Man would soonest overtake ye, as I'me a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Son Tom, Tace, proceed Madam.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: But in spite of all my industry, this wild Welsh Creature has still found me out, and has publish'd himself and me, in so particular a manner, that here I am in a Lampoon again, and in so filthy a stile, that I vow I'm asham'd to read it.

sp.speaker: Shink.
sp.p: What signifies running into Closets, and Cellars, and Larders, was not all her Doors left open, can her deny that?

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Alas, I had not presence of mind enough, to shut the Door upon him, this is my deplorable case, Sir Charles, and if he does not Marry me, I must never shew my Face in the World again, I am utterly undone, as I'm a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Shink
sp.p: Her has been as much undone; look you in Cellars, and Closets, fery often before Shinkin's found her there, as report goes, and to be prief, her shan't marry Harridans and Wildcats, and there's, there's the resolution of a true Prittain, look you.

sp.speaker: Squeam.
sp.p: Never particular with any Person, since I was born before, as I'm a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Well, well, go after and teize him, this business must be debated at a more convenient hour, for I see the Entertainment is going forward, here comes my Daughter,—now Tom mind your business.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Cousin, no more, the proofs are clear and manifest, and as you relish my proceedings, second me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Against the World, in such a generous action.

div.stage: Enter Mummers, and Sir Quibble, disguis'd amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Pray, what are these, Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh, these are Mummers, some of the young fry of the Neighbour-hood that having a frolick this Evening, desire to give us a share on't, the Subject is the stealing an Heiress, and the Figures are Love, Desire, Youth, and Avarice, that all Court the Lady Pecunia, the design is pretty enough, come let 'em begin.

div.stage: Then enter Frederick and Quickwit disguis'd like Pluto and Orpheus, Marmalet following.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Here's more, what are these?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh, this is Cunnington's contrivance, a little masque of Pluto, Orpheus, and Euridice, pray let's observe.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: They desire to practice with Euridice a little in the next room, and then you shall see 'em do it perfectly. Come, Madam, this is the rarest contrivance to escape that ever you had.

div.stage: Fred. takes one of Fulvia's hands, Quickwit the other, and as they are leading her off she turns back

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Hold, hold, are ye mad? why, Sir Charles, and you Squire Small-brains, you will not suffer me to be carried off thus before your faces, will ye?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: But into the next room to practice a little, Madam.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: You are to act Euridice, you know, Madam, and they will only see if you are perfect in your cue; Mr. Cunnington there, has shewn me the whole design.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: And Mr. Quickwit, the witty Player here, has shewn it me, Sir. Come, Pluto, you must unmask.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Dsdeath, Madam, what d'ye mean, you wont discover us, and undoe all?

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Yes faith, Sir, I've a fancy in my head that 'tis not lucky to be stolen to day; therefore you Orpheus, otherwise call'd Frederick the constant, you must uncover too, your singing will hardly get ye a Mistress to night, I can assure ye.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: She discovers us—Death and Confusion! what new turn's this?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Methinks, Mr. Heiress-stealer, you look very blank o'th' sudden.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis so—this is the Female Devil that has done me this admirable good turn, I find it now, and my disgrace approaching: Oh! damn'd! damn'd Fortune!

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: What think ye now, Sir Charles? am I not very just to my Guardian?

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: This is such an affront, as nothing but my Sword can do me justice in.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Gad take me, the Devil's in 'em for plotting, I think; will they never let us alone?

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: That Devil Quickwit in the Plot agen! I hope you'll give him one good thrust for my sake.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Nay, no fighting, good Gentlemen: Well, well, Sir, I understand ye, but you are so hasty—
sp.stage: Sir Quibble endeavours •… o pull her aside, and she refuses.
sp.p:
Lookee, Sir Charles, here's another part of the Jest remains still, which this Gentleman Mu •… er is wittily concerned in too, who having no ill opinion of himself, and consequently
believing I had a very good one of him, sent me word he was bail'd, and his present design of mumming, bribing some of his Tenants to act it, and help carry me off; and is really, and in specie, the very numerical and amorous Knight, Sir Quibble Quere.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: Sir Quibble Quere too? why, here are all the Fools in the Nation sure, concern'd in this Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: 'Dsheart, why will you discover me now, Madam? I'll say't, 'twas the purest design that ever was laid, but I hope you'll marry me for all this, for you know I have laid out a pour of Money upon't, and have now a Coach and six Horses ready at the Garden-gate for ye, I'll say't, you ought to consider now, Madam; what a dickins, Conscience is Conscience all the World over.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Learnedly argued, Sir Quibble, and you shall see what Justice I'll do you all presently; first you, Sir, that through the To Fred. baseness of your sordid nature, and mercenary thirst of gain, abus'd me, take that as a reward for your Ingratitude and my Eternal hatred for the future.

div.stage: Gives him his promise of Marriage to Sophronia.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: My contract of Marriage to Sophronia!—this is the Thunderbolt I always dreaded, and 'tis fall'n with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Read there a base Deceiver's Character, and for thy sake may never generous Maid, trust thy false Sex to be again betray'd.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Instead of Heiresses and blooming Brides with fifty thousand Pounds, Stick to your old Doll Commons of the Town,
And cater as you us'd for half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Peace, Witch, Fury, now could I eat that Satyrical Devil without Salt for my Breakfast! Torture and Death! to stay here too, and be baited, is worse than breaking upon the Wheel!—Hell take all Heiresses, and all the Sex besides.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, alas poor Brother, I see now I am to be the happy Man.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Troth no, Sir, I must beg your pardon too—your Estate is wasted with disbursing Sums to go a Fortune-hunting; nor have you Brains enough to get another, and to marry a Ninny, a Bankrupt, no, as you us'd to say, Sir, I a'n't such a Fool neither.

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: You may send home your Coach, Sir Quibble, you will have no use for it here, Gad take me.

sp.speaker: Sir Quib.
sp.p: Why then a Plague of all Intrigues: I'll go and get drunk, and despise all Womankind, for I'll say't, I'll ne're hang my self about the matter, but I'll have my Money again if there be Law in England, let the Women go to the Devil, I'll not be chous'd out of that; what a Pox, I a'n't such a Fool neither.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—thus far, Sir Charles, you see how far I have discharg'd your Trust, do ye resolve therefore to deliver up your Guardianship freely, that I may have generous liberty to pursue my Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p:
Madam, with all my heart, before this Company I declare you free to chuse a new Guardian where you please, and to confirm it,
take there the Keys where all your Writings are, and the Power left me by your Father,—I see she intends to give her self generously to my Son, and therefore to confine her, were ungenerous.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: There stands the Gentleman, Madam, if you design him happy, the quicker work the better.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: That might have been done, indeed, Doctor, to oblige Sir Charles, but the Gentleman you speak of, has made a better choice, as this can witness.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: How's this! a Letter of Courtship to Sophronia!

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Oh! and so full of Passion, Flame, and Darts, that it almost scorch'd me when I read it.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Oh Villain! Dol •… ! Town-Fop! have I been racking my Brains all this while to get an Heiress to thy purpose! what's the meaning of this, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: T. Rom.
sp.p: Why the meaning is, that I love all the Sex, gad take me, and can no more confine my self to one Woman, than to one Suit of Cloaths; if you don't like the humour you might have got me a better, that's all I know of the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Char.
sp.p: Insupportable Coxcomb! I'll disinherit thee immediately.

sp.speaker: Guiac.
sp.p: More turns and Plots, this is a very Comedy, by the life of Gallen.

sp.speaker: Ho •… sp
sp.p: So, I find I am like to Cudgel my five hundred Pounds out of my Spark, for the Devil a pen •… y •… e's like to get by the Heiress—but stay, who the Devil will she chuse,—if I should be the Man at last.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Since such a general defect of honesty corrupts the Age, I'll no more trust Mankind, but lay my Fortune out upon my self, and flourish in contempt of humane Falshood: as for thy part that hast been a main Acter in this business, and with contriving wit well manag'd it, to let thee see th' Ingenious still gets Friends, I will with Gold reward thy Industry, nor shall honest Numps, may, nor your Co •… ade, be either of the •… forgotten,—but be instantly brought hither, and share a part of Bounty.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: 'Tis my Glory, Madam, to be outwitted by you, and if my Brain did any thing uncommon, it was by you inspir'd.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Well, 〈◊〉 Fortune has contriv'd the business, so I hope, Sir, you think it time to remember me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Oh, prithee, dear venerability, have patience a little, thou •… eest all the Marriages are 〈◊〉 at present, and 'tis not fit we should be singular, my dear Antiqu •… .

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Alas, sweet Sir, but delays you km •… w are dangerous, and if I should be balk'd in my Expectation, my heart is so set upon' •… that I should anihilate that very moment, I should dye, as I'm a Christian.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: Well, Cousin, what think we now of my Resolution, have I not done Justice?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
Most generous Maid, thou art a dear Example for all th •… S •… to copy out thy Virtue, for that a kind and tender heart like 〈◊〉 ,
moulded for Love, and softned with Endearments, should generously on the account of honour, resist a Traytor, that with strong E •… hantments of Vows and Oaths, had long time made Impression, is a performance heightned to a wonder, and will be reverenc'd in succeeding ages.

sp.speaker: Fulvia.
sp.p: My eyes in contradiction to the World, have ever (scorning Interest) fix'd on Merit, and led by Love and Generous inclination, have strove to make that Sentiment appear by a free present of my Heart and Fortune to one I thought as nobly had deserv'd 'em. But, oh! the Race of Men are all Deceivers, and my relief, is my resolve to shun 'em; 'tis, my dear Friend, as thou hast lately told me, which for instruction I will still repeat.

lg.l: Love may seeem great that in it self is small,
Looks cover thoughts, and Interest governs all;
When Damon to an Heiress speaks kind things,
'Tis not for what she is, but what she brings.
OF all the Criticks met to judge this Play,
The Fortune-Hunters most are fear'd to day;
Who must be vext that they've a Brother found
So odly balk'd of fifty thousand Pound:
And I confess they have some cause to rage;
The Spark has lost a tempting Equipage,
A Coach, a set of Barbs, such dazling things,
Nay, six lac'd Footmen finer than the Kings;
Besides a fine bred Miss embroider'd round
With a Rump Croshe •… worth five hundred Pound.
But yet considering the equality,
How oft ye chouce poor Women, is't not fit
Once in an age the Biter should be bit;
To be so often fool' •… I think is civil,
But to be Changelings always is the Devil.
Besides, the truth is, we find out your Arts.
Love guilds your Tongues, but Money guides your Hearts;
